Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how media can have a huge affect on public perception of medicine.

This was a pretty good summary since the turn of the 20th century of Medicine and how it has changed in the history and context of a changing America. Learn lots of cool facts about the history of America and specific medical things in our history, but not a lot of tools to use outside the class.
I learnt a lot in this course. I have an interest in medicine but did not know much about the history of medicine.
This class gives an interesting history of how the media has influenced America's understanding and perception of disease and medicine.

I understood how media and medicine interact on a variety of different industries like tobacco, primetime tv, AIDS and  pharmaceuticals. There are more complications between the two industries regarding ethics, marketing, consumerism and risks/benefits.
Media and Medicine was an extremely fun lecture that taught many relevant topics to the health care world today and the past.
I learned much more about studying media and the different forms that it has.
This gave me a great understanding of the major pieces media and medicine since the late 19th century in America.
Very interesting class overall.

I received an incredible amount of knowledge about the history of media and medicine from 1880 to the present. I now have a much better insight into the profession of medicine and how media works and shapes society in general. I also developed skills in recognizing broad historical concepts and creating questions that I would like to answer myself in the future about this incredibly rich and interesting topic.

I learned a lot about the history of media in relation to medicine. I also learned about campus resources such as the medical historical library. The lectures were interesting and taught me about topics that are important to consider when going into the field of health.
This class helps to tie together themes of public health, socialization, media, consumerism, pharmaceuticals.
You learn a lot about how movies, tv, advertisement campaigns, and activist moments effected the greater health movement.
This is actually one of the courses at Yale that I've left feeling like I understand how history has shaped medicine today- super applicable content and fun lecture!
Historical and contemporary influences of media on medicine
I gained a better understanding of how the media has played a huge role in how we perceive the medical field.

Tons of historical information on media and medicine. Thought about the effects of media in a way I never had before. Really cool to see the interaction of things that happen everyday in the background that maybe you're not aware of. Also gained skills in writing effective thesis essays.
Not that much that I didn't already know just from living in America. I learned a bit about certain health movements in history that I didn't know about..
I learned how the media affects medical breakthroughs, treatments, and public perception of advancements in the medical field.

I learned all about the history of medicine through the media and educational campaigns from the 1880s to the present. This included topics such as tuberculosis, polio, AIDs, HIV, obesity, mental illness, and STDs. We learned about how the media portrayed each of these medical cases and the stigmas, techniques, and reactions which came with them.
I learned a lot about how the medical establishment fits into politics throughout modern history. It was really interesting subject material.
Learned a lot about the complex history of medicine our country. Really did not know nearly as much as I do now at the beginning of the course.
Awesome class, went over just about everything regarding the media in the early 20th century
Substantial overview of the social history of medicine, modern influences, and strong instances of racial discrimination, stereotyping etc.
Learned lots of factual information. Not much beyond that. The course could have used more critical thinking, especially in section.
Great overview of the history of public health crusades in America from the late-19th century to present day.
Overview of medicine in the media since the 1880s
I learned about media campaigns that had impacts on the medical field.

This course aided in my ability to connect historical events and trends to our modern day society. I also found it very interesting to learn about the modern day consequences of media involvement in medicine.
Lecture was super interesting!! There is a good balance between the history and the modern aspects! Very engaging lecturers!
Learned to write essays around the idea of a historical question and all of the material was very interesting, most of which I had never learned before.
I learned about various public health issues in U.S. history and contemporary times, and how the media affected these public health issues.
Scattered information about media and medicine interaction, important milestones is public health, and somespicy scandals
I learned a lot of things I didn't know about healthcare in America.
I learned about the relationship between media and medicine in the U.S. since from the late 1800s to the modern day.
I learned about the interplay of the histories of media and medicine in order to understand the origins of medicine in America.
Learned how media and medicine were intersected in the 20th century

I gained knowledge about the growth of media and medicine together throughout the last 140 years in America, particularly regarding public sentiment, patient empowerment, and the stature of the medical industry. I also learned about social issues within medicine, such as gender roles and discrimination. Lastly, I learned of both past and present ways that the medical industry used/uses media to reach the public, what is effective in that field, and why.

Being a STEM major and who had taken a more general public health class in a previous semester, this class was particularly fascinating as it introduced another aspect of how medicine and science is portrayed and conveyed through media. It was fun to see how primary source media (i.e. movies, advertisements, posters, videos, etc.) were analyzed and how they contributed to medicine's role in society. It was different from the more general overview course that I had previously taken in the sense that media was the main focus.
This is a well-structured and generally fascinating American Studies lecture. Go to class! Not much work and a really interesting/crucial story being told here.
I came away with a solid understanding of the intertwined relationship between medicine and media. Media plays a major role in driving people's expectations of medical care.
I developed a good sense of how the media general impacts medicine throughout American history.
The history of medicine since the late 1800s, from the Golden Age of Medicine to the Death of Deference, to the current social-media-infused culture of medicine.
The course presented some interesting history, but I didn't feel my critical thinking or analysis skills were in any way challenged. Overall, I didn't learn much.
Media medicine allows you to see the trends that have affected the public's perception of media throughout history.
I developed an understanding of how media and medicine have interacted over the last 140 years, and how they have shaped one another.
I learned a ton of history through a medical and/or media perspective and it was very interesting to tie previous information I already had and the things I learned in this course together.

This course is a good overview of the role that the media has played in shaping medicine and will definitely help you to understand/see modern health advertising in a different way. However, no topics are analyzed in depth, the course is not very structured and the lectures feel a bit like a collection of historical facts about different advertising campaigns.

a basic background on the way various forms of media have shaped public opinion of medicine and healthcare since around 1875. helps you see different health campaigns and medical "breakthroughs" in a new light.

I learned a lot about the history of medical campaigns as portrayed by the media and interpreted in broader society alongside important political contexts. This course focused on broad themes and trends, which was a useful way to conceptualize all of the information without having to memorize specific dates.
This was an interesting class about the history of the relationship between media and medicine.
An overview of the connections between the mass media and the medical community over the last couple centuries.
I thought this class taught me a fair amount about the subject but since I had taken other American Studies courses I'm not sure I developed any particularly new skills.
I learned about how different groups can influence each other and how media portrayal can color any situation in a certain way.
If you pay attention, you learn so much about the history of medicine and the media in the US! Would recommend!
The class did well in integrating two seemingly distinct topics. It was very useful in building historical analysis skills.
Interesting topics and readings, lecture can be a bit dry sometimes and lack of assignments encourage basically doing nothing

strengths - very insightful 
weaknesses - professor became monotone a lot of the time and sometimes it was hard to keep up and pay attention in lecture
Professors Warner and Berland were both very knowledgeable but their lecturing styles were pretty boring. If the material was interesting it was fine, but that was a 50/50 in its own right.
The lecture slides do not go posted so although I went to lecture I found it difficulty to type my notes and keep up with the speed of the lecture.
The course does a great job at presenting the material in an engaging manner. The readings were a bit overwhelming and too hard to get through, especially if one is not an HSHM major.

Overall great course. Sometimes the readings were a bit much, but you don't really need to read it to do well in the course. Otherwise I really enjoyed it, especially the use of lots of media in class.

lectures were incredible and very engaging. I don't think anything could be better about lectures. My sections was also very engaging and helpful to understand the material better. I really liked the format of the class as well--very straight forward but interesting and relevant to our lives today.
I think the lectures are great.
I really enjoyed section and think that's where a lot of my deeper understanding came from.

The strengths of the course are that the material is incredibly interesting, the readings are extremely well chosen, and the professors both offer very unique perspectives and insight into the topic. It could be improved in that the section meetings could be a little more exciting. The only thing is that the overarching objective of the final paper could have been communicated better instead of just how to write well for it.

The grading was far more strict than I anticipated. I went to every lecture and did all the readings, but did worse on the midterm than I did in any of my stem classes, which was frustrating. I feel like effort in the class was not reflected in grades, a sentiment shared by many peers.

Overall I loved the lectures and while the final paper was challenging and somewhat vague, it was a good learning experience. The readings were very interesting.
This course is very repetitive and moves at a slow pace.

The strength of this course was undoubtedly the expertise of Professors Berland and Warner in presenting such an expanse of time filled with important events in a palatable and engaging matter. I really loved lectures. The big weakness was that your experience, and feeback in the course in general, depends entirely on the quality of TA you are assigned to. I'm sure it's hard to screen for quality in TAs but the lack of engagement and cooperation in our section as a result of our TA really tainted the experience for me and, I fear, my grade. Comparing experiences with my friends in other sections was a bit disheartening.

Strength:
- It is easy while being interesting
Weakness:
- The readings are dry
-Lectures can be disjointed because there are two professors lecturing from different time periods
TFs are weirdly harsh graders but the course is great- switching lecturers every other class spices things up in a good way

strengths: very interesting material

weakness: extremely confusing organization, bounce around in time for no reason, would be an AMAZING course if chronological (I understand they try to organize the course in themes, but chronological order would be much more straight forward)

The strength of the class was that the TAs are very helpful to ensure that you understand the material provided in class and prepare you for the exams. The weakness is that the lectures can be a little dense.

Strengths: Super interesting and informative. Professors were both great and engaging. My TA was very engaged.
Weaknesses: Too many readings. And the classroom was not a good location/didn't have wifi or desks to write on.

The course was not at all challenging but also the professors and TAs were never up front about their expectations. I think that in order to really get more out of the course and enjoy it more, it would have been helpful to know what was expected of me! For instance, for the exams I learned pretty much everything from the course (dates, people, big ideas, etc). I wrote what I felt was a really good and cohesive response to the questions but then the feedback I got was "good, seems like you know everything, I would've liked to hear you talk more about this!" But there's no way that anybody could know that without getting inside the TA/Professor's head. The grading really didn't reflect what student's knew. It seemed like in part because it was such an easy course, they just graded kind of randomly in order to have a better distribution of grades rather than giving all As which is kind of annoying.

The class covered a lot of interesting events that occurred in the medical field with the media throughout history and it was a very interesting course. Some of the lectures were a little boring though.

This class covers a broad range of material looking through the lens of medicine. By learning about the state of medicine at the time and how the media portrayed it you learn a lot about history as well due to the historical context which I thought was really cool. The lectures were very engaging because we analyzed old posters and photographs as well as watched some videos about topics like mental illness, venereal disease, and tuberculosis. Furthermore, the readings were interesting and pretty manageable. The only thing I would suggest is to have the lecture slides uploaded on Canvas.

Both lecturers were a little quiet (probably because it was in the YUAG), but I thought the lectures were very engaging and interesting since they had so much media and film. I understood the need to go non-chronologically, but that was sometimes a little confusing. However, I think section can make or break the course-- I didn't have a great experience with my TA, so the exams were unnecessarily difficult and stressful.
Great course in terms of the breadth of material and the discussions/themes explored by the professors - definitely more than just a history course. Good incorporation of media examples
The strength of the course were the topics and the lectures. The course was weakest in connecting different lectures to one another and maintaining a continuous theme throughout the semester.
Lecture was fun and interesting; yet I would like to see the lecture slides posted on Canvas- sometimes it was hard to write down what was on the slide/refer to videos or audio clips.
Really interesting lectures; easy workload
The strength of this course is the actual media we were able to engage with on a daily basis. However, the lecturers were often dry and not interesting.
The use of the big screen to show videos made the lectures much more fun and interesting. I found the lectures to be my favorite part of the class.
I didn't love that the historical lectures and the modern were taught at the same time organized by themes. Would've preferred to go chronologically.
The involvement of the TAs is incredible, show true passion for the course material and want all students to be engaged and learn.
This course is very interesting. The weakness is that there is a midterm and a final exam that both consist of simply writing. This is not useful. The class should just have two papers.
Very relavent to daily life. Made me more medically informed.
Powerpoints are not available after lectures, so one must rely on notes to study for this class. The pace of lecture by no means facilitates notetaking, though.
I think the course needs to cover womens health more thoroughly. I feel like it is an obvious topic to include but it was missing from the curriculum almost entirely.

The topic of this course is very interesting. I like the lectures from week to week and the information is interesting and relevant.

I think that the course could be improved with less or shorter readings. I would also like if more of the slides could be posted (or, if picture copyright is a concern, at least some form of lecture notes or summary of relevant information) to make it easier to study. Finally, I think that the tests could be improved. I would appreciate if there were some kind of guidelines (like a grading rubric or sample essay) and, in the case of the picture questions in the midterm, if the questions were a little more recognizable/easier to write about.

I personally thought the professors were a huge strength of this course, I found both very engaging and structured lecture well. 
I also found the topic and the approach to history in a broader sense a huge strength. This course was extremely useful for general understanding of the world around us. The only weakness I can think of was maybe a lack of communication with the professors, but TAs were extremely engaging and very helpful so it wasnt a big deal.

Strengths: Fascinating Subject Matter
Weaknesses: Readings were poorly discussed (if at all) and lectures could be terribly dry.

The lectures were pretty interesting and section was good for highlighting the important information of the week. The readings were sometimes long and dry, and perhaps trimming the longer readings to focus on specific sections of them would be beneficial.

Professors did not post the lecture slides with the media/text that they analyzed which made it slightly more difficult to study for exams, but it was cool that they brought in guest lecturers that were able to provide a different perspective on topics; class was in the YUAG, which was fitting for a large lecture class, but there were no desks to write on - I really didn't like that aspect as especially for exams, I need to write on a desk or someone solid instead of on a wooden board.
The paper can be entirely unrelated to the content of the course. Overall, the course was very well run and engaging. Very little I would change.
I thought this course did an excellent job utilizing section to cover topics more in-depth and I think it should continue to do that.
Very interesting lectures, but professors are a bit quiet, so it is sometimes hard to hear. Sections are phenomenal.

The course lectures and readings converged largely around the same 5 or so themes the entire semester, yet for some reason the lecturers only made oblique references to these themes, while much could be clarified by organizing lectures around them and not using them instead as test questions.
Love that one Prof is doctor and other is historian, provides rich and multifaceted context for various events and time periods.

This class had the potential to be incredibly interesting and fell extremely short. I felt that the class was run like a straight history lecture with a few interesting movies and media tidbits thrown in. There was never really any critical discussion of the media in question, nor did we ever connect anything in this class to current events.
The course is interesting, but can be a bit jumbled. Things rarely flow in chronological order which can make it a bit confusing.

The course draws connections between entertainment, medicine, public attitudes, and historical events. I enjoyed this broad overview, but if someone wanted a very focused, specific course this wouldn't fill that role. I think the broader view is a strength.
I wish the course included fewer longer films instead of many short clips.

The strength of this course was that it was very straightforward with the information and that it was easy to understand in the given themes. This made for a much more sensible studying fashion, as you can understand what's happened in themes or in chronological order, especially if you pay attention in lecture. The major weakness of this course was the lack of order of the information as it's given to you. Lecture topics were very interesting but all over the place in terms of order throughout the semester. Any review session gives a clear timeline, though, and it's easy to make your own.
Not enough depth/critical analysis, the course looses structure and a clear progression as the semester progresses. Could be more intellectually challenging and bring topics together better.

The lectures were always pretty interesting, and both Professor Warner and Professor Berland are really interested in what they teach. The class focuses on media, so it's always very helpful to see the images or video clips they share as part of the lecture content. Something I found myself wishing while studying before exams is that important names and dates had been included in the slides, just to make sure I got them down when taking notes. I also thought the review session held by Megann before the final exam was super helpful!!

I think more of the material shown in lecture could be offered online, like images and video clips, for future reference when going over notes by one's self. Overall, as an HSHM major, I thought that it was a great course that brought together many themes I'd talked about in other HSHM classes, through the lens of the media.

This course had a lot of redundant and repetitive information (i.e., the golden age of medicine, the rise and fall of the medical profession...) but i did like the two professor structure, because their areas of expertise complemented each other very well.
I thought it was an interesting course with a lot of great material.
The course was great, but I wish the slides went online!
I thought some of the readings were incredibly dull and others were relatively interesting. Lecture was hit or miss.
Fascinating content and engaging section
Strengths- Great lectures, but some class subjects aren't necessary, or even tested on exams.
The course strengths were in the material and readings. The only weakness I can think of is that the final paper did not have a specific rubric to follow.
Yes if you are a HSHM major or just in general interested in public health or media, totally take it.

Good for a Hu credit. The material is actually interesting and you can engage yourself as much as you want to in the readings/lectures. The only work in the week was readings for section (as much as that means to you), a paper, and the midterm/final studying.
Yes, take M&M! Super interesting class and so many things covered.
Yes - but I do believe whether you do well or not depends on your TA and how he/she grades.
YES! This course is really interesting and also not a lot of work! It completely changed my life by making me realize what kind of classes/major I should be doing.
Absolutely would recommend this course to any student. Its an incredible class that can be relevant to any major at Yale.

Media and Medicine is an amazing lecture and was I was excited for the lectures throughout the semester. Although there is a lot to read, you can pretty much skim through the readings for section. The exams were also pretty reasonable, as long as you paid attention during section and lecture. Overall, you will learn a lot of interesting and fun aspects on the history of the American health care world.
I think the course material is interesting and the structure allows the student to investigate what they find interesting about it.
This is a very interesting class even if it's not within your major, it applies to a lot of different fields within lectures (mental health, advertising, gender roles, race, medicine, etc.).
This class is a gut depending on your TA.

The lectures are really interesting and worth going to. The topics you explore and discuss are all very relevant to our lives and important to think about as a person constantly exposed to all kinds of medicine-related media. The workload is very reasonable and not hard to keep up with.

I would definitely recommend this course to others because it's a really great class that offers incredible insight into a profession and medium that have both profoundly shaped our lives in ways we didn't even realize.
The lectures are interesting and I liked the course, but be wary of the grading. It was far stricter than anticipated.

Yes, this was a great class. Be aware that your experience is going to almost completely depend on the quality of the TA you get. If after the first couple of sections anything seems off, I'd book it to another section. Hopefully that will save you from the trouble I experienced! Otherwise, this course is SO interesting. As a STEM major, I learned a lot about history and of course media and medicine. But for me it was really great to plug in the scientific timeline I had in my head to historical events and to understand mindsets throughout the 20th century. Super cool and would recommend.
Yes, it is not a lot of work and this knowledge is worth having.
yes! super interesting, fun course.

This is actually one of the courses at Yale that I've left feeling like I understand how history has shaped medicine today- super applicable content and fun lecture! also it's low key a gut because most of the exam prompts are common sense lol
Would definitely recommend if others were interested in the intersect of media and medicine in America.

I loved this class. I thought the material was super interesting, the professors were engaging and the readings weren't super heavy and were very reflective of what was being taught. Definitely a chill class to take if you are interested in history or medicine.
Yes!
Yes! Super interesting for everyone. I'm an econ major and wanted a humanities credit. This one was perfect for me. I really liked the material and the workload is minimal.

Not really - the course is really low workload which can be nice but I wouldn't say it's just an easy A. The grading depends pretty much solely on your TA and different TAs have different expectations and grade differently. However, it was really hard getting just grades back without any feedback on ways to improve. Overall a very frustrating course. I can't say I learned a lot.
Yes, it is a great way to learn about the involvement of media in the medical field and it opens one up to a new side of medicine often unseen to the average person.

Yes, this was a nice, relaxing, fun course where I still learned a lot about history, medicine, and how the media influences how we see things. While we learned about a lot of past campaigns, many of the techniques and stigmas can still be seen today and it's cool to now be able to recognize and watch out for those now. This class also only had a midterm, a seven page paper, and a final. This is a great class for a STEM major who needs a HU credit.
Yes-- if you're at all interested in film, history, medicine and public health, it's very interesting and important.
yes
Yes!
Take it !!! Media and Medicine has been one of the most interesting courses Ive taken at Yale.  As a science major it was a great Hu credit too.
Absolutely take this if you are at all interested in how the media has shaped our healthcare in the United States
Absolutely! Even if you're not an HSHM or even premed, the course was very insightful and has changed how I approach media advertisements.
Take this course.  It teaches you a lot of important things about the state of medicine in America.
Yes, good overview of the history of medicine and public policy in America.
Yes! This class is so great. Lectures are really interesting, the topics are relevant to everyone's lives, and the workload is not bad at all. I would definitely recommend this class

Yes, I have actively recommended this class to other students because it gives historical context to medicine and its effect on media and vice versa. Thought it was a very interesting history course for non-history majors.
Take it. Light workload, interesting content, easy to retain. It is a win win.
Yes! If you're interested definitely take it! It's not a ton of work and really interesting! Only a midterm, paper and final!
Yes. The TAs and lecturers are amazing. Material is very interesting and accessible. Great humanities class.
I would recommend this course to anyone mildly interested in public health or medicine. The topics covered are extremely important for everyone to know who plans on entering these fields.
Yes! Awesome course
If you need the HU credit; yes.
Yes, it was very interesting and informative.
Yes

I didn't particularly enjoy this class, but it was okay, and I wouldn't recommend against it if you are interested. The lectures were average in terms of content/excitement, the material was easy enough to comprehend/learn, readings were kind of long and not always exciting (but on par with other HSHM lecture courses). Midterm and final consist entirely of essay questions -- not my preferred format and I didn't feel like I was given enough guidelines to be prepared to give the kind of answers they wanted at first (plus the midterm is pretty rushed), but I know a lot of people found the tests to be easy enough so I think it just comes down to stuff like your preferences, strengths, and TF/section.
I loved this class, it convinced me to change my major to HSHM, and it may be my favorite class Ive taken at Yale so far.
Take it, very interesting and it makes you want to go to class
This is a decent course. There is a midterm, final paper, and final exam. You won't really get much feedback on the midterm, so proceed accordingly.

I would recommend this course because it is centered around two entities that are very present in our lives, and the history and growth of media and medicine is quite interesting. The workload is fine, and it's a class that allows you to determine your level of engagement by how much work you put in.

I would recommend for both film majors and pre-med/STEM majors alike since I found this subject interesting even though I do not plan to major in HSHM. The workload is not terrible; the readings are the basis of what is talked about in lecture from Prof Warner and Berland; discussion section is once a week, this class is different from other non-STEM classes I've taken since media analysis is at the center, instead of more contextual things; TA did not really given super clear feedback in the beginning on how to improve that; lectures are also not posted on Canvas, so in order to make the best of the class, you should take diligent notes
The individual lectures were usually interesting, but the course was disorganized. I would have preferred a more chronological approach to the material.
Yes! Anyone considering a career in medicine / science or a career in media / journalism would benefit from taking this course. Really enjoyed it!
I definitely would recommend this class. It was an excellent class and had a reasonable course load.
Most definitely. The material is fascinating, it really contextualizes the current culture surrounding medicine.
No. This course is on unique subject matter, however, it does not merit and entire semester worth of lectures.

Yes, very interesting, a little gutty, but I learned a lot and I enjoyed myself. This class is probably really easy to get an A- in, but really depends on your TA's specific interests to get an A in, which I think is quite unfair.

This class will superficially expand your knowledge of how the media has historically influenced medicine. It will not touch on any current events and modern media, nor will it challenge your thinking in any way. Take it if you like sitting in history classes memorizing facts.
This course is great if you are looking for something that is interesting, related to medicine, and a low work load. Great 5th class.
I would recommend this course to another student because it has extremely interesting content and touches on really important topics from interesting angles.
Yes, I would recommend the course. The material is fascinating, the lecturing good, and the workload is such that you can actually enjoy the course without being overwhelmed. I definitely recommend!
Media and Medicine is a great course! You analyze films, books and posters that relate to medicine. Enormous numbers of premeds + midterm/7 page paper/final.

Yes! Many lectures were so interesting because they were on topics that we would know of/understand/like and then go deeper into the semantics of how/why they came about. It wasn't overly full of historical terms or boring lectures, so take it!
would 100% recommend to another student. Not hard for the amount of information you are learning. Interesting material and pretty easy workload

I would recommend this course to another student because the workload is pretty light and very manageable. I will say that going to lecture helps if you aren't able to do all of the readings, because the lectures usually give you a pretty good understanding of important events and content that will be needed for the exam.
Great HSHM class, not too much work but interesting lectures.
No doubt about it, this class was a gut.

This course was interesting as it allowed you to view medicine in a different light. I enjoyed surveying media campaigns over time, and seeing the progression of medical progress from the 1800s onward.
Absolutely, a great HSHM course that everyone should take.
Yes, it was very interesting and a really cool way to look at the media throughout history.
I felt this course was pretty easy. Paper was not hard, exams felt doable. Take it if you love media or medicine. Would consider it mildly gutty.
Yes would highly recommend, to those looking to fulfill a requirement
I would recommend this class to another student.
I would recommend this class to another student especially those who are interested in medicine.
